p: Soil-borne diseases are major crops yield-limiting factors threatening food security worldwide ( Erper et al., 2008). Fungal plant pathogens like Pythium spp., Rhizoctonia solani, Thielaviopsis basicola, Verticillium spp., Sclerotinia spp., Phytophthora spp. and Fusarium spp., have been cited as causative agents ( Abawi and Pastor-Corrales, 1990). They may each infect independently the host causing characteristic symptoms, or in complexes, resulting in more severe cases ( Erper et al., 2008). Among soil borne diseases, Fusarium root rot (FRR), caused by the fungus Fusarium solani f. sp. phaseoli (Fsp) W.C. Snyder & H.N. Hansen has a cosmopolitan distribution. The former prevails wherever common bean ( Phaseolus vulgaris L) is grown across the world. In fact, F. solani causes hypocotyl rot, seeds and seedlings decay at pre and post-emergences (damping-off) and root rot in common bean, with substantial yield decline culminating at as high as 100% in susceptible cultivars ( Mukankusi et al., 2011; Nzungize et al., 2012).
